title: 114_s1476
content: The Act may be cited as the "Police Reporting Information, Data, and Evidence Act of 2015" or the "PRIDE Act". It establishes the Community and Law Enforcement Partnership Grant Program. The Attorney General will provide grants to eligible States and Indian tribes for activities outlined in subsection (c). To be eligible, a State or tribe must report incidents and make their use-of-force policy for law enforcement officers publicly available. Reporting of incidents to the Attorney General is required annually. The Indian tribe must report to the Attorney General any incidents involving shootings or use of force by law enforcement officers or civilians resulting in serious bodily injury or death. The Indian tribe must report incidents involving shootings or use of force by law enforcement officers or civilians resulting in serious bodily injury or death to the Attorney General. The reported information should include details such as gender, race, ethnicity, age, date, time, location, armed status, type of weapon, and type of force used. The Indian tribe must report incidents involving shootings or use of force by law enforcement officers or civilians resulting in serious bodily injury or death to the Attorney General. Details to include are gender, race, ethnicity, age, date, time, location, armed status, type of weapon, and type of force used. States or Indian tribes can use grants for various activities. Reporting under the death in custody reporting act does not require incidents reported before the date of the report. The curr_chunk discusses the use of grants by States or Indian tribes for reporting requirements, incident investigation systems, public awareness campaigns on use of force against police officers, and use of force training for law enforcement. The Attorney General is required to conduct an annual audit and review of the information provided. The Attorney General must annually review data from States and Indian tribes receiving grants to ensure compliance. A report must be published publicly within a year of the Act's enactment. Privacy protections under the Privacy Act of 1974 must be upheld. Guidance on best practices will be issued within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The FBI will provide guidance on data collection systems for reporting use of force incidents. The Attorney General is authorized to allocate funds for implementing the Act.
